title: How the Price of Crude Oil Affects Gas Prices - The Balance
summary: Crude oil prices significantly influence gas prices, accounting for around 61% of gas costs as of February 2022. The remainder of the gas price includes refining, distribution, corporate profits, and taxes. Historical trends illustrate that oil and gas prices have been volatile, especially since the 2008 financial crisis, with peaks often associated with geopolitical events, such as Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which escalated gas prices to a record high in March 2022. Market factors like supply and demand and speculative trading in oil futures also impact prices. OPEC, comprising 13 oil-producing nations, plays a crucial role in regulating oil prices by controlling the supply. The U.S., as a major oil consumer, alongside China and India, experiences fluctuating demand. Speculative trading in oil futures can lead to asset bubbles, affecting prices even when supply is ample. The U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve serves as a buffer during supply disruptions.

title: EIA forecasts crude oil prices will fall in 2022 and 2023
summary: The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) forecasts declining crude oil prices for 2022 and 2023, with Brent crude averaging $75 per barrel in 2022 and $68 per barrel in 2023, compared to $79 per barrel in late 2021. This decline is attributed to a shift from inventory withdrawals in 2021, caused by higher consumption relative to production, to inventory increases in subsequent years as production outpaces consumption. Global petroleum production is expected to rise, driven by the United States, OPEC, and Russia, while consumption growth slows slightly but continues to increase, especially in the U.S., China, and India. These dynamics are projected to put downward pressure on crude oil prices.
snippet: In the fourth quarter of 2021, the price of Brent crude oil, the international pricing benchmark, averaged $79 per barrel (b). We forecast that the price of Brent will average $75/b in 2022 and $68/b in 2023. The declining prices are driven by a shift from global petroleum inventory declines during 2021 to inventory increases in 2022 and 2023.

title: The Relationship between Crude Oil and Natural Gas Prices
summary: The document explores the relationship between crude oil and natural gas prices, noting that historically they were maintained at a 10-1 ratio but have shifted to a 6-1 ratio. This shift is attributed to the adoption of combined cycle gas turbines, enhancing the efficiency of natural gas in electricity generation. The analysis concludes that U.S. natural gas and crude oil prices remain linked in the long term but can be influenced by external shocks like weather and inventory changes. The study highlights that crude oil prices affect natural gas prices indirectly through competition with residual fuel oil, and technological advancements in energy generation have significantly impacted the price relationship. The findings emphasize the importance of considering technological changes and short-term market factors in understanding energy price dynamics.

title: Crude oil prices are sinking. So why are gas prices still high?
summary: Crude oil prices have significantly decreased, dropping over $20 a barrel from their March peak, yet gas prices in the U.S. remain relatively high. The average price at gas stations is $4.11 per gallon, only a 5% drop during the same period. Economists explain this discrepancy by noting that gas stations are slow to reduce pump prices when crude oil prices fall, allowing them to profit from the difference. An imbalance in supply and demand, exacerbated by supply chain delays and increased demand following COVID-19 lockdowns, contributes to high gasoline prices. However, decreased oil demand from China due to COVID-19 shutdowns might soon ease market tightness, though it is unclear how quickly this will impact U.S. gas prices. The U.S. Energy Information Administration expects average prices to be around $3.80 for the year.

title: Decline in gas prices provide much needed relief at the pump for ...
summary: The average gas price in Georgia has steadily declined, now at $3.55 per gallon for unleaded—14 cents lower than the previous week—due to increased refinery capacity and crude oil prices dropping below $100 per barrel. Factors include reduced demand as drivers limit unnecessary trips and economic slowdown concerns. However, prices may rebound if refinery operations are disrupted, such as by hurricanes. For contractors like Paulo Neto, the savings are significant, with his truck refueling costs dropping from $130 to $90 in two weeks.

title: Why Gas Prices Rise Faster Than They Fall - US News & World Report
summary: Gasoline prices rise faster than they fall due to factors like existing inventory purchased at higher costs, competition among stations, and strategic price adjustments to maximize profit margins. Stations delay lowering prices to recoup losses and benefit from higher margins during price drops. Refineries also profit as gasoline prices can remain high due to lower inventories, even if crude oil prices decrease. Market dynamics, including the separate supply-demand fundamentals of oil and gasoline, contribute to this disparity, with refineries sometimes influencing prices by controlling supply. While gasoline prices may eventually drop, fluctuations in crude oil prices add unpredictability.
